Wait, in racing terms, the number of laps completed indicates their finishing position. A higher lap count means they completed more laps and thus finished higher. So if Surer has 65 laps, that's more than Boutsen's 54, meaning Surer actually finished higher (earlier) than Boutsen? But the claim says Boutsen finished right after Surer, implying he was just behind.

Hmm, perhaps I'm misunderstanding. Maybe the lap count indicates how many laps they completed before retiring or finishing. So if Surer completed 65 laps and Boutsen 54, that means Surer finished the race with more laps than Boutsen, but since 65 is higher, maybe Surer was ahead of Boutsen? But I'm getting confused.

Wait, in a grand prix, the race has a set number of laps, say 70 or something. If both drivers didn't finish, their lap counts would be less than that. So if Marc Surer completed 65 and Thierry 54, it's possible that Surer retired after completing more laps but Boutsen finished fewer laps. This doesn't directly indicate their finishing order.

Wait, perhaps the grid position can help. Surer started at 9, while Boutsen started at 8. So Boutsen was one position ahead of Surer on the grid, but that's starting position, not finishing position.

I need another approach. Maybe the time or reason for retirement can show who finished when. But I don't see their times here, only reasons like suspension or exhaust.

Alternatively, perhaps in the 1985 Dutch GP, Boutsen and Surer were close in the race finish. Let me think about what I know: Thierry Boutsen was a Belgian driver known for his speed but also had some issues. Marc Surer is another driver who had races where he didn't finish.

Looking at their lap counts again: Surer did 65, Boutsen 54. If the race had more laps, say 70 or 75, then both retired before completing all laps. But which one finished closer to the end? The higher lap count means Surer completed more of the race than Boutsen.

So, in terms of finishing position, if a driver completes more laps, they are further along in the race. So Surer would have finished higher (more laps) than Boutsen. But the claim is that Boutsen finished right after Surer, meaning Surer was ahead, which aligns with Surer having higher lap count.

But wait, I'm not entirely sure because sometimes drivers who complete more laps can still finish earlier if they were lapped by others. So perhaps Surer was leading and then retired, while Boutsen followed a bit later.

Alternatively, maybe the grid positions don't necessarily reflect finishing order since faster drivers can overtake. But without their times or official standings, it's hard to be precise.

Given that, I think the key is that both drivers did not finish the race because Surer had an exhaust issue and Boutsen retired with suspension. So they both didn't complete all laps, but Surer completed more than Boutsen, implying he was ahead in the race when he retired, and Boutsen came after.

Therefore, Thierry Boutsen did finish right after Marc Surer in the sense that Surer had a higher lap count, meaning he finished closer to the end before retiring. So the claim is plausible based on their lap counts indicating their finishing order.
